Description: Low power range for delicate ceramics like porcelain to avoid thermal cracking; typical for 1064 nm Nd:YAG systems in heritage and industrial cleaning. Recommended starting at 30 W for light contamination. Max safe ~100 W before risk of substrate damage due to low thermal conductivity (~1.5 W/mK). Source: Manufacturer specs (e.g., CleanLaser CL 50 model) and studies on ceramic restoration (e.g., J. Cult. Herit. 2018).
Near-infrared wavelength optimized for Porcelain absorption and minimal substrate damage
Beam spot diameter for precise cleaning control on Porcelain surfaces
Optimal repetition rate for efficient cleaning coverage and thermal management
Nanosecond pulse duration for effective contaminant removal with controlled thermal effects
Optimal scanning speed for uniform cleaning efficiency
Recommended number of passes for complete contaminant removal
Optimal beam overlap for uniform cleaning coverage without excessive thermal buildup
